prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for telling his girlfriend she doesn't need to make plans every time he wants to game. They've been together for three years and live together now. The main issue seems to be that the girlfriend feels neglected when he plays games and expects her to have plans. The author argues that she doesn't need to go out just because he's gaming.

First, I need to consider both perspectives. The author mentions that he's trying to balance his gaming time with his relationship. He's given up a lot of free time for their relationship before, but now that they live together, he wants to game with friends. The girlfriend, on the other hand, feels she gets no time to herself and expects him to involve her in plans, leading to arguments when she can't make them happen.

The key points here are communication and mutual respect. The girlfriend feels her needs aren't being met when he's gaming, which is a valid feeling. She wants quality time together, and when he's gaming, she might feel excluded. The author, however, is trying to maintain his own interests and social life, which is also important for a healthy relationship. The problem arises when one person's needs overshadow the other's without considering compromise.

The author's response to the situation—telling her she doesn't need to make plans and can just relax on her phone—might come off as dismissive of her feelings. Even if he's not going anywhere, she might need more than just passive presence. The girlfriend's reaction of leaving to her sister's house indicates she's hurt or frustrated, which the author didn't address adequately. Instead of explaining his need to game, he should have discussed finding a middle ground, like setting specific times for gaming and other times for couple activities.

In relationships, both partners need to feel valued. The author's insistence on gaming without considering his girlfriend's emotional needs could lead to resentment. His justification that she can just watch him play might not account for her desire for active engagement. The fact that the girlfriend felt the need to make plans each time suggests she wants to ensure she has her own space or time, which the author dismissed by saying she doesn't need to go out. This could be seen as not respecting her emotional boundaries.

On the other hand, the author has a right to his own hobbies and social interactions. The issue is how he communicated this. Instead of a confrontational approach, a more collaborative discussion about balancing both their needs would be better. The author might not be entirely wrong, but his handling of the situation shows a lack of consideration for his girlfriend's feelings, which is a problem.

So, considering all that, the author is in the wrong because he didn't address his girlfriend's feelings adequately and didn't seek a balanced solution. The answer should be A.
